﻿THE CODE OF WILKES COUNTY, GEORGIA ____________ Published in 2018 by Order of the Board of Commissioners ____________
WILKES COUNTY OFFICIALS ____________ Sam Moore County Commission Chair ____________ Esper Lee, District 1 Ed Geddings, District 2 Charles Jackson, District 3 Clem Slaton, District 4 County Commissioners ____________ Charles LeGette County Attorney ____________ Karen Burton County Administrator PREFACE

PREFACE This Code constitutes a codification of the general and permanent ordinances of the County of Wilkes County, Georgia. Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the ordinances adopted by the county board. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. Chapter and Section Numbering System The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. Page Numbering System The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes:
Indexes The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. Looseleaf Supplements A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. Acknowledgments This publication was under the direct supervision of Mary Margaret Bielby, Code Attorney, and Kellyn Wilcox, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. The publisher is most grateful to Karen Burton, County Administrator, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that her efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the county readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the county's affairs. Copyright All editorial enhancements of this Code are copyrighted by Municipal Code Corporation and Wilkes County, Georgia. Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; state law references; numbering system; code comparative table; state law reference table; and index. Such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of Municipal Code Corporation and Wilkes County, Georgia. © ;hg;Copyrighted material. Municipal Code Corporation and Wilkes County, Georgia. 2018.

div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "The Code of Wilkes County, Georgia," and may be so cited. This Code may also be cited as the "Wilkes County Code." State Law reference— Codification requirements, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-19. Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. The following definitions and rules shall apply to all ordinances of the board of commissioners, unless the context requires otherwise: Generally. The ordinary signification shall be applied to all words, except words of art, or words connected with a particular trade or subject matter, when they shall have the signification attached to them by experts in such trade, or with reference to such subject matter. In all interpolations, the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the county commission, keeping in view, at all times, the old law, the evil and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate, and a transposition of words and clauses may be resorted to when the sentence or clause is without meaning as it stands. While subpart A is a codification of general ordinances and subpart B is a codification of ordinances pertaining to land development, provisions in subpart A may also apply to land development and provisions in subpart B may also apply to activities other than land development. The failure to include in subpart B provisions that relate to land development does not excuse noncompliance with such provisions. The inclusion in subpart B of provisions that relate to activities other than land development does not excuse noncompliance with such provisions. Liberal construction; minimum requirements; overlapping provisions. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the board of commissioners may be fully carried out. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the other provisions of this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. Adequate. The term "adequate" means equal to what is required, suitable to the case or occasion, fully sufficient, proportionate or satisfactory. Aforesaid. The term "aforesaid" usually means next before. All. The term "all" means everyone, or the whole number of particulars. Also. The term "also" means "in like manner," "likewise," "in addition," "besides," "as well," "further," "too." As soon as possible. The term "as soon as possible" means within a reasonable time, having due regard to all the circumstances. At. The term "at" may mean "in," "near," "within," or "about." Its primary idea is nearness, and it is less definite than "in" or "on." Board of commissioners, board, commissioners, commission, county commission, governing authority and governing body. The terms "board of commissioners," "board," "commissioners," "commission," "county commission," "governing authority" and "governing body" mean the board of commissioners of Wilkes County, Georgia. Code. The term "Code" means The Code of Wilkes County, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. Computation of time. When a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years, or other measurements of time except hours is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; and, if the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1, the party having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation Commission. Wherever the term "commission" is used, the same shall be held to mean the "county commissioners of Wilkes County." Conjunctions. In a provision involving two or more items, conditions, provisions or events, which items, conditions, provisions or events are connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either…or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows, except that in appropriate cases the terms "and" and "or" are interchangeable: (1) "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply. (2) "Or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly or in any combination. (3) "Either…or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly but not in combination. County. The term "the county" or "this county" means Wilkes County, Georgia, outside the corporate limits of the City of Rayle, City of Tignall, and City of Washington. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring a county officer or county employee to do some act, it is to be construed to authorize the officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the act. Easement. The term "easement" means a right, liberty, privilege or advantage without profit which the owner of one parcel of land may have in the lands of another; or a right in the owner of one parcel of land, by reason of such ownership, to use the land of another for a special purpose not inconsistent with a general property right in the owner. Following. The term "following" means next after. Gender. The masculine gender includes the feminine and the neuter. Highway. The term "highway" includes any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass and causeway in the county, dedicated or devoted to public use. Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons or officers may be executed by a majority of them, unless it is otherwise declared. Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean and include persons acting by themselves or as a servant, agent or employee. Land and real estate. The terms "land" and "real estate" include rights and easements of an incorporeal nature. May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive. Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. Must. The term "must" is to be construed as being mandatory. Number. The singular and plural number include the other, unless expressly excluded. Oath. An "oath" includes an affirmation. O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as amended. Official time standard. Whenever certain hours are named herein, they mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use in the county. Officials, employees, boards, commissions, etc. Reference to officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies of the county by title only refer to the officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies of the county. Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and" and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. Person. The term "person" extends and is applied to associations, corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as individuals. Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property, as herein defined. Preceding. The term "preceding" means next before. Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. Public place. The term "public place" includes any place that the public is invited or permitted to go or congregate. Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as mandatory. Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark of an illiterate or infirm person. State. The term "state" means the State of Georgia. Street, road. The term "street" or "road" includes any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, lane, viaduct and any other public highway in the county, including, but not limited to, the paved or improved surfaces thereof. Tenant or occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies, the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. Until a certain day. The term "until a certain day" includes all of such day. Week. The term "week" means seven days. Whereas. The term "whereas" means "considering that." Will. The term "will" is to be construed as being mandatory. Writing. The term "writing" includes printing and all numerals. Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. State Law reference— Computation of time, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1; meaning of certain words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; time, O.C.G.A. § 9-11-6. Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes; editor's notes; references. (a) The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of such sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (b) The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Cross references, state enabling legislation references, state law references and editor's notes which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. (c) All references to chapters, articles or sections are to the chapters, articles and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. State Law reference— Notes and catchlines of code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7. Sec. 1-4. - Applicability of Code. The provisions of this Code, unless otherwise clearly specified, shall apply only in the unincorporated areas of the county. Sec. 1-5. - Effective date of ordinances and resolutions. Except as otherwise provided by law, ordinances and resolutions which do not provide for their taking effect at a different time take effect immediately upon adoption. Sec. 1-6. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person in the county to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the county to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. State Law reference— Altering, falsifying or stealing public records unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1. Sec. 1-7. - Amendments; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code of ordinances by the commission. (b) Every proposed ordinance shall be read twice, once at each of two distinct meetings of the commission, except that both the first and second readings thereof shall be done by reading the caption thereof only, unless, upon motion and a majority vote of the commission, the commission requests the reading of the proposed ordinance in its entirety; provided, however, that the commission may provide that the proposed ordinance be read in its entirety at only the first or second reading thereof; further provided, that at any reading of a proposed ordinance, the mayor or other presiding officer may require that a synopsis be given of the proposed ordinance, either before or after the reading thereof. In case of emergency, an ordinance may be read twice by unanimous consent at the same session and passed. The reading of a proposed ordinance, in the event of such emergency, shall be done in the same manner as other proposed ordinances, in accordance with the provisions of this section. (c) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section ____________ of The Code of Wilkes County, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. (d) In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That The Code of Wilkes County, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article, chapter or other designation as the case may be), to be numbered ____________ , which reads as follows:…." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. (e) All sections, articles, chapters or other provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number, article number, chapter or other number, as the case may be. Sec. 1-8. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by county personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the board of commissioners. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the commission or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. (b) In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. Sec. 1-9. - General penalty; continuing violations. (a) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means: (1) Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; (2) Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; or (3) Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (b) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a county officer or county employee to perform an official duty unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. (c) Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance, rule, regulation or order of the county any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in the Code or any ordinance, rule, regulation or order the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of that provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule, regulation or order shall be punished by the proper court by the imposition of a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, or imprisonment for not more than six months, or any combination thereof. (d) The imposition of a fine or penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise. (e) Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a fine or penalty does not prevent equitable relief. State Law reference— Magistrate courts, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-1 et seq.; violation of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq.; punishment for misdemeanors, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3; maximum punishments which may be imposed for violations of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(b); county responsibility for sentencing and maintenance of inmates, O.C.G.A. § 42-5-51(a). Sec. 1-10. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. (a) The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. (b) The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. Sec. 1-11. - Severability of parts of Code. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the board of commissioners that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court or competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the commission without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. State Law reference— Severability, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-3. Sec. 1-12. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing legislation. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances and resolutions existing as of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-13. - Matters not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any of the following ordinances not codified in this Code: (1) Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (2) Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds for the county, or any evidence of the county's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the county. (3) Any appropriation ordinance. (4) Any ordinance approving the budget. (5) Any ordinance fixing salaries of officers or employees of the county. (6) Any right or franchise granted by the county to any person. (7) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, defining, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the county. (8) Any ordinances or resolutions prescribing traffic regulations for specific streets. (9) Any legislation providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor. (10) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the county. (11) Any ordinance rezoning property or otherwise pertaining to zoning. (12) Any ordinance adopted for purposes that have been consummated. (13) Any ordinance that is temporary, although general in nature. (14) Any ordinance that is special, although permanent in nature. (15) Any ordinance levying or otherwise relating to taxes. (16) Any ordinance amending any act enacted by the general assembly of the state. Sec. 1-14. - Code does not affect prior offenses, penalties, rights. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (b) The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance in effect on the date of adoption of this Code.

Sec. 2-204. - Intent and scope. This division is intended to comply with the policy requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24 regarding the use of county-issued government purchasing cards and credit cards. (Ord. No. 12102015, § I, 12-10-2015) Sec. 2-205. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Authorized elected official means an elected official designated by public vote of the board of commissioners to receive a county-issued government purchasing card or credit card. Card administrator means the purchasing card and credit card administrator designated by the county board of commissioners. County purchase card, county p-card or county credit card means a financial transaction card issued by any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, used by a county official to purchase gods, services and other things of value on behalf of the county. Financial transaction card means an instrument or device as the term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-9-30(5). User agreement means the required agreement between the board of commissioners and the authorized elected officials which restricts the use of a county purchasing card or credit card. (Ord. No. 12102015, § II, 12-10-2015) Sec. 2-206. - Designated elected officials. (a) The county board of commissioners ("county"), in its discretion, may authorize specific county elected officials to use a county purchasing card or credit card by adoption of a resolution in a public meeting. (b) No authorized elected official may use a county purchasing card or credit card until and unless he has executed the county's purchasing card and credit card user agreement. (c) The county will not make payments to any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, for amounts charged by an elected official to any purchasing cards or credit cards that are not issued pursuant to this division or for any purchases that are not authorized by this division. (Ord. No. 12102015, § I, 12-10-2015) Sec. 2-207. - Card administrator. The board of commissioners shall designate a county purchasing card and credit card administrator. The responsibilities of the card administrator include: (1) Manage county-issued purchasing cards and credit cards. (2) Serve as the main point of contact for all county purchasing card and credit card issues. (3) Serve as liaison to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff, as well as to the issuer of the purchasing card or credit card. (4) Provide training on card policies and procedures to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff. (5) Develop internal procedures to ensure timely payment of cards. (6) Assist authorized elected officials to dispute transactions when necessary. (7) Establish internal procedures to ensure compliance with this division, county procurement ordinances and policies, county purchasing card and credit card user agreements, applicable agreements with the business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, issuing card, and state law, specifically, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-9-37 and 36-80-24. (8) Document internal controls, audits and other measures to prevent and detect misuse or abuse of the cards. (9) Audit and reconcile transactions monthly. (10) Maintain records for at least seven years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. (Ord. No. 12102015, § II, 12-10-2015) Sec. 2-208. - Use of cards. (a) Authorized purchases. (1) County purchase cards and credit cards may be used to purchase goods and services directly related to the public duties of the authorized elected official only. All purchases are subject to the terms of this division, the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, county procurement policies and ordinances, and the adopted budget. (2) Only authorized elected officials may use a county purchase card or credit card for purchases or payments. The cards, and use of the cards, are not transferrable to employees. The authorized elected official shall use care to ensure that others do not have access to the card account number, expiration date and security code. (3) Unless otherwise approved by the governing authority or established in the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, the transaction limits are as follows: a. Per transaction ..... N/A b. Per month ..... $5,000.00 (b) Unauthorized purchases. County purchasing cards and credit cards shall not be used for goods and services not directly related to the official responsibilities of the authorized elected official. Additionally, cards shall not be used to avoid compliance with the county's purchasing ordinances and procedures, to purchase goods and services that are not approved in the county's budget, to purchase goods and services exceeding the per transaction or per month limit, or to make purchases not in compliance with the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement. (c) Receipts and documentation. (1) Receipts, invoices and other supporting documentation of all purchases made with a county purchasing card or credit card shall be obtained and maintained by the authorized county elected official for five years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. (2) If an original or duplicate cannot be produced, a sworn affidavit of the authorized elected official may be substituted. The documentation must include the supplier or merchant information (i.e., name and location), quantity, description, unit price, total price, price paid without sales tax and an explanation of the purchase sufficient to show that the expense was in the performance of official county duties. (d) Public records. All receipt and other documentation of purchases are public records and subject to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. (Ord. No. 12102015, § III, 12-10-2015) Sec. 2-209. - Review of purchases and audit. Proper documentation of purchases, internal controls and other measures prevent and allow detection to misuse or abuse of county-issued purchase cards and credit cards. Authorized elected officials and staff that process payments under this program shall cooperate and comply with the procedures established by the county. (1) Review of purchases. a. O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24(c)(7) requires the county to establish a procedure where purchases are reviewed. To ensure timely and proper payment by the county of the charges each month, the county needs to establish a procedure for the elected officials to turn in documentation to the card program administrator or other person processing accounts payable for the county. b. All purchases shall be reviewed according to the following procedure: Credit card and receipts are to be turned in to the administrative office immediately upon their return or within five days. All receipts are to be detailed and signed by the elected official. (2) Audits. The card administrator shall perform an annual review of the card program to ensure adequacy of internal policies and procedures, cardholder spending limits, monthly reconciliation procedures and documentation for transactions. Elected officials and staff shall cooperate with such review. (Ord. No. 12102015, § I, 12-10-2015) State Law reference— Process for auditing and review must be developed. O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24(c)(7). Sec. 2-210. - Violations. (a) An elected official shall reimburse the county for any purchases made with a county-issued purchase card or credit card in violation of this division or the user agreement. (b) In the discretion of the county governing authority, failure to comply with the procedures outlined in this division may result in: (1) A warning; (2) Suspension of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card; or (3) Revocation of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card. (c) Nothing in this division shall preclude the county governing authority from referring misuse of a purchase card or credit card for prosecution to the appropriate authorities. (Ord. No. 12102015, § I, 12-10-2015) State Law reference— Procedures for addressing a violation, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24(c)(8).

div.head: Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; Local regulation of alcoholic beverage manufacture, distribution, and sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-40 et seq.; Signs advertising alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-3.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Short title. This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Wilkes County Alcoholic Beverage Control Ordinance." (Ord. No. 01232012, § I, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § I, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, malt beverage, wine, or fortified wine as defined in this section, and beer. Bona fide private club means any nonprofit association organized under the laws of this state which: (1) Has been in existence at least one year prior to the filing of its application for a license to be issued pursuant to this chapter; (2) Has at least 75 regular dues-paying members; (3) Owns, hires, or leases a building or space within a building for the reasonable use of its members, which building or space: a. Has suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment; and b. Is staffed with a sufficient number of employees for cooking, preparing, and serving meals for its members and guests; and (4) Has no member, officer, agent, or employee directly or indirectly receiving, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages beyond a fixed salary. Calendar year means the period of time from the date of issuance of a license on or after each January 1 to the date of December 31 of the year of issuance of said license. Clerk or county administrator means the clerk or county administrator of the board of county commissioners. Designated county official means the person designated by the board of commissioners as inspectors for the purpose of inspections as cited in the definition of the term "inspection" in this section. Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 24 percent alcohol by volume. Election day means any general election, primary election, run-off election, special election, or referendum within the unincorporated areas of the county. First public notice means the date of the posting of the sign required in section 4-25(a) on the premises. Fortified wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 24 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term "fortified wine" includes, but is not limited to, brandy. Inspection means a health and building inspection will be conducted each year prior to renewal of retail license and prior to issuance of a new license. Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other similar product or any combination of such products in water containing not more than 14 percent alcohol by volume and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer and strong beer. The term "malt beverage" does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Restaurant means any establishment which is licensed to sell alcoholic beverages and which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross income from the sale of on-site prepared meals or food and which has a seating capacity of not less than 30 persons. School means state or county school or such other schools (public or private) as teach subjects commonly taught in common schools and colleges of this state, and inclusive of day care centers that may supervise five or more children at one time. Special event means an event that is to be held in a place other than the normal establishment licensed for the sale of beer and wine in the unincorporated area of the county. Such event shall be organized with provisions for security (including traffic control), fire protection, medical services, and assurances of compliance with all federal, state and local laws, rules and regulations. Said event shall also include provisions for any un-named items that may be required by the board of commissioners considered necessary for the safety and protection of persons and property. Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 24 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes, either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term "wine" includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combination of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term "wine" does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. (Ord. No. 01232012, § II, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § II, 6-12-2014) Secs. 4-3—4-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSING
Sec. 4-23. - License required. No person, firm or corporation shall offer for sale or sell any alcoholic beverage within the unincorporated areas of the county without first obtaining the appropriate license herein required. (Ord. No. 01232012, § III, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § III, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-24. - Application. (a) Each applicant shall apply to the clerk or county administrator for a license by written application on forms approved by the board. All questions and information requested on the application form shall be filled in and subscribed to by all applicants. (b) All applications must be filed at least 30 days prior to the date considered by the board. This may be waived in the case of a special event. (c) Applications will be considered and licenses granted only at a regular meeting of the board. This may be waived in the case of a special event. (d) No license shall be granted to any person who is not a citizen of the state or to any person who is less than 21 years of age. (e) If the owner of the business is an individual, the application shall be made by such individual unless he is not a citizen of the state, in such event, the application shall be made by a person who is a citizen of the state and who is actively engaged in the management of the business for which such license is sought. This may be waived in the case of a special event. (f) If the ownership of the business for which a license is sought is a partnership or corporation, the application shall be made by one of the partners or an officer of the corporation who is actively engaged in the management of the business. In the event that no partner or officer is a citizen of the state, then the application shall be made by a designated agent of the business who is a resident of the state and who is actively engaged in management of the business. (g) In the event that a firm, partnership or corporation owns or operates more than one place of business in the county, all applications for licenses for each place of business made pursuant to this article shall be made independently. In the case of a special event, a permit may be issued for each location where beer and wine will be sold during the time of the event, through a locally approved license holder. (h) If the application is being made on behalf of a private club, the application shall be made by an officer of such private club. (i) No person shall be granted a license unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the board that such person is of good moral character and the business or private club which he represents enjoys a good reputation; and in no event shall any such license be granted to any person who has been convicted or plead guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any felony, crime of moral turpitude, or misdemeanor of a high and aggravated degree within a period of five years immediately prior to the filing of the application. (j) If an application is refused or withdrawn after being placed on the board's agenda for consideration, no application for the same location will be accepted for one year from the date of the filing of the application when reapplied for by the same person or business. (k) The building in which the sale of beer and wine will occur, must be inspected prior to the issuance of a new license. This may be waived in the case of a special event. Said inspection will be to assure that the building and contents are considered safe and no health hazards are evident. Applicant must obtain a statement from the designated county official attesting to the health and safety of the building and contents. (Ord. No. 01232012, § IV, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § IV, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-25. - Advertisement. (a) Except in the case of a special event for which the board of commissioners has allowed a waiver, all persons desiring to engage in the sale of malt beverages or wine shall give notice of their intention to make such application by advertisement in the form prescribed by the board. (b) Advertising by the applicant for original license shall mean that there shall be a sign posted in a prominent position on the building, if there be one (it may be on or in the front window where it can be read from the road), at least 30 days prior to consideration of the application by the board. In the event there is no building on the premises, the notice shall be posted on the lot where said building is to be erected. (c) The wording and specifications for the sign which must be posted when applying for a new alcoholic beverage license may be updated from time to time by the county commission and kept with the county clerk. (Ord. No. 01232012, § V, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § V, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-26. - Application fee. Every application, excluding renewals, shall be accompanied by a non-refundable application fee in the amount to be established by the board, from time to time. (Except in the case of a special event, see section 4-29.) Said fee shall be paid to the board and shall be credited toward the license fee if a license is granted. (Ord. No. 01232012, § VI, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § VI, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-27. - Investigation; recommendations. The applicant shall be directed to the sheriff's department, who shall have the applicant investigated. All fees required to conduct said investigation shall be paid by the applicant to the sheriff's department at the time of request. The sheriff's department shall cause the character and reputation of the applicant and suitability of the location (inclusive of any required measurement of distances) of the establishment for which the license is sought to be fully investigated. The applicant shall be finger-printed and photographed for record and investigated for past criminal history. The applicant shall sign a release form to allow information gathered by the sheriff's department to be summarized and reported to the board. Only after all of the foregoing requirements have been fulfilled will the application for a license be considered by the board. (Ord. No. 01232012, § VII, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § VII, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-28. - Hearing; consideration; denial of license. (a) All applications presented shall be noted as to the date of filing and, after filing, such application shall be presented and considered by the board in the order of their filing at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board, provided 30 days have elapsed after the date of filing. This may be waived in the case of a special event. (b) In determining whether or not any license applied for hereunder shall be granted, in addition to all the other provisions of this article, in the public interest and welfare, the following will be considered: (1) The applicant's reputation, character, mental, and physical capacity to conduct this business. (2) Whether the person has previously had an alcoholic beverage license suspended or revoked. (c) No license shall be granted to any existing building or establishment having a history of or reputation for prostitution or other sex offenses; fighting; shooting; stabbing or other violence; gambling; illegal dealing in alcoholic beverages or drugs; or other violations of the law. The term "history or reputation" means within the one year next proceeding the filing of said application and provided said business is now owned, operated, managed, or in any way connected to the person operating said business during the times these offenses occurred. (d) No license shall be granted for the sale of malt beverages or wine from a building occupied as a dwelling or any building attached to a residential dwelling or within 50 feet of any residential dwelling. (e) No license shall be granted for the sale of malt beverages or wine from a building inspected by a designated county official and sited for any health violations or safety violations as to the building or contents. (Ord. No. 01232012, § VIII, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § VIII, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-29. - Annual license fees. (a) The following annual license fees shall apply for the sale of alcoholic beverages. Such license fees shall be established by the board, from time to time: (1) Retail: beer and wine. (2) Wholesale: beer and wine. (3) Alcohol beverage caterer's license. (4) Special event. (b) When a license has been approved and granted, the fee for same shall be paid to the board in the full amount of the license fee (less any credit due). (c) The annual license fee shall cover the period from January 1, or date of issuance if after January 1, through December 31 of each year. (Except in the case of a special event). There will be no pro-rating of any license fee. (Ord. No. 01232012, § IX, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § IX, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-30. - License period; lapse for nonuse. (a) All licenses shall be issued for a calendar year. In case of the revocation or surrender of a license before the expiration of such calendar year, the holder thereof shall not be entitled to receive a refund whatsoever. (b) All licenses must be obtained no later than 90 days from the date of approval of the application, and, if not so obtained, said license shall be void. (Ord. No. 01232012, § X, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § X, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-31. - Renewal; denial. (a) All licenses granted hereunder shall expire on December 31 of each year and shall be renewable at the option of the board. Licensees who desire to renew their licenses shall pay the required fee for such renewal on or before December 31 of each year. Failure to secure the renewal by December 31 shall result in a loss of license and the owner will be required to file for a new license at the new license fee. (b) The board may grant or deny, for cause, the renewal of any license. (c) Each November, a designated county official shall visit each licensed site to make an inspection to ensure no health or safety problems exist and issue a statement to the board recommending approval or denial of renewal. If denial is recommended, the county official shall state the reason and immediately notify the license holder. The official will return for a follow-up inspection two weeks after the notice is written. The applicant will be assessed a fee for any follow-up inspection to be determined by the board, from time to time. Failure to correct the sited violations within the two-week period will be just cause to deny renewal of the license until all violations are corrected. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XI, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XI, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-32. - Sale of business. (a) In the event that an individual, corporation, firm, or partnership sells the business at which a license issued hereunder authorizes the sale of malt beverages and wine, such license shall automatically terminate; provided, however, if an application is filed by the new owner within 15 days from the date of purchase pursuant to the provisions of this article, the clerk or county administrator or is hereby authorized to issue a temporary permit allowing such business to continue the sale of malt beverages and wines until such new application can be processed in accordance with the terms of this article. (b) Said temporary permit allowing such business to continue may be issued upon receipt of a non-refundable fee paid to the county by the applicant and to be determined by the board, from time to time. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XIII, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XIII, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-33. - Transfers. (a) A license may be transferred between immediate family members, when limited to the members having interest in the same business (spouse to spouse; spouse to son or daughter and vice-versa; brother or sister to brother or sister). (b) In the event that the holder of license on behalf of a corporation or private club ceases to be an officer of such corporation or is no longer associated with such private club, such corporation or private club shall apply within 15 days after such event has occurred for a new license to be issued to the person holding the same office as the previous licensee. In such event, a fee to be determined by the board, from time to time, shall be paid to the board. (c) No license shall be transferred from one location to another unless the new location meets all of the standards required by this article and such transfer is approved by the board. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XIV, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XIV, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-34. - Suspension or revocation. (a) Any false or misleading information contained or material omissions in the application for a license shall be cause for the denial thereof, and if any license has been granted under such circumstances, same shall be subject to revocation. (b) Should any licensee be convicted, plead guilty or plead nolo contendere to any felony, crime of moral turpitude, or misdemeanor of a high and aggravated degree, such license shall be and stand immediately and automatically revoked and canceled. (c) The board shall have full power and authority to revoke, refuse to renew, suspend or place on probation any license to sell malt beverages and wine for violation of this article or any other county ordinance or violation of any state or federal laws. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XV, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XV, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-35. - Display or posting on premises. The county license shall at all times be posted in a conspicuous place within the building, and if said license is not so posted, said business shall not be authorized to sell alcoholic beverages until same shall be posted. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XVI, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XVI, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-36. - Hours and days of sale and operation. (a) No license holder shall engage in the sale of malt beverages or wine except between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. on weekdays (Monday through Friday) and 6:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Saturdays; and 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on Sundays; and shall not permit the sale of malt beverages or wine on Christmas Day or any other day on which the state law prohibits the sale of malt beverages and wine. (b) All establishments must close by no later than 2:00 a.m., Tuesday through Saturday, and shall be completely vacated of patrons and shall not reopen prior to 6:00 a.m. In the instance of Saturday night, all establishments must close no later than 1:00 a.m. on Sunday morning and shall be completely vacated of patrons and shall not reopen prior to 6:00 a.m. on the following Monday morning. (c) Grocery or convenience stores where the principal business is the sale of groceries and other like items, and restaurants where the principal business is the sale of prepared food, and the sale of malt beverages and wine is incidental thereto, may remain open during other hours but shall not sell or allow to be consumed any malt beverages or wine except during the times and hours specified in subsection (a) of this section. (d) The business hours of wholesale dealers shall be the same hours and days as retail dealers are allowed to engage in the sale of malt beverages and wine by the terms of subsection (a) of this section. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XVII, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XVII, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-37. - Location. No license shall be issued hereunder where the place of business is located within 200 yards of any school or church. All distances herein referred to shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground and shall be measured in the following manner: (1) From the front door of the structure from which alcoholic beverages or wine is sold or offered for sale. (2) In a straight line to the nearest public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway. (3) Along such public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway by the nearest route. (4) To the front door of the building, or the nearest portion of the grounds, whichever is applicable under the appropriate statute. (5) Measure to the property line, if a church. (6) Measure to the property line, if a school. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XVIII, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XVIII, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-38. - Sale to minors, incompetents, and inebriates. (a) No malt beverage or wine shall be sold to a minor under any conditions whatsoever. A minor, for the purpose of this article, shall be considered to be a person under the legal age as provided by state law. (b) No malt beverage or wine shall be sold to any intoxicated person, nor shall any intoxicated person be allowed to remain upon the premises of any place of business selling malt beverages or wine. (c) No employees of any business selling malt beverages or wine shall work in said place of business while intoxicated and no employees shall drink malt beverages or wine while working and employed in such business. (d) No malt beverages or wine shall be sold to any person who is mentally incompetent. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XIX, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XIX, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-39. - Compliance with health rules. All retail licenses under this article are hereby required to comply with all rules and regulations and requirements of the county board of health, state board of health and any and all other state, federal and local public health authorities. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XX, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XX, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-40. - Penalty for violation. (a) Violation of any provisions of this article for failure to comply with any of its requirements shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any person who violates this article or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished according to section 1-9, general penalty. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. (b) In addition thereto and totally and separately distinct there from, any violation of any of the provisions of this article or failure to comply with any of its requirements shall be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of any and all licenses, regardless of the number of locations involved, and regardless of whether or not the holder of the license knew or contributed to such violation. It is the intent of this subsection without limiting the generality of the foregoing to grant the board the right to suspend or revoke any or all licenses held by a licensee when any violation of this article occurs at any place of business where alcoholic beverages or wine are sold pursuant to a license issued hereunder. (c) Any violation of the general statute law of the state pertaining to alcoholic beverages or wine shall constitute a violation of this article. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XXI, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XXI, 6-12-2014) Sec. 4-41. - Due process. (a) Under this article, the board has the discretionary power within the guidelines of due process as hereinafter defined to grant, refuse, and to suspend or revoke any license in accordance with the standards set forth in this article. (b) All decisions by the board denying, suspending, or revoking such licenses shall be in writing with the reasons there for stated and mailed or delivered to the applicant personally within ten days from the date of the decision by the board. (c) Upon application within ten days of the receipt of the notice of denial, suspension, or revocation, the applicant shall be afforded a hearing with an opportunity to present evidence and cross-examine opposing witnesses. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XXII, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XXII, 6-12-2014) Secs. 4-42—4-61. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAX[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Municipal and county excise tax, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80.
Sec. 4-62. - Imposed on malt beverages and wines; audit, report and remittance of sales. There is an excise tax hereby imposed on malt beverages and wines in the maximum amount allowed by law, as now exists or hereafter amended. (1) Said tax shall be paid to the board by each wholesale dealer on all malt beverages and wine sold within the unincorporated areas of the county not later than the tenth of each month, based upon the units of beer and wine sold during the previous calendar month of said wholesalers to retailers in said county. (2) The wholesale dealer shall keep true and correct records of all sales and shipments and shall render a sworn statement of the same accompanying the monthly report and payment to the board and said report shall show the exact quantities of malt beverages or wine, by size and type of container and the amount of excise tax collected. (3) The board shall have the right to audit, and to require production of records from each retailer so supplied. (4) Failure to make a timely report and remittance of aforesaid taxes shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount due, in addition to the amount due; and additionally, if said report is not filed or if said taxes are not remitted and paid within 30 days from the date that the same are due, the board shall have the right to suspend and/or revoke any wholesale license, and further to prohibit said wholesaler from making any deliveries of any type whatsoever within the unincorporated areas of the county and to report such action to the state. (5) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell retail or otherwise within the unincorporated areas of the county any malt beverage or wine on which the tax required in this article has not been paid to the wholesaler or distributor or the board of the county. (6) All holders of alcohol beverage caterer's licenses shall be liable for collection and timely payment of all excise taxes due on sales at special event. Additionally, special event organizers should ensure that said tax is paid on all alcoholic beverages in such a way that the county receives benefit from taxes paid. In addition, special event organizers should ensure that all applicable sales tax is collected and remitted in such a way that the county benefits from taxes paid. (Ord. No. 01232012, § XII, 1-23-2012; Ord. No. 06122014, § XII, 6-12-2014)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Animals generally, O.C.G.A. title 4; Responsible Dog Ownership Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. At large means off the premises of the owner and not under restraint, supervision or control. Court means the magistrate court of the county. Humane manner means care of an animal to include protection from injury, adequate coolness and heat, ventilation, sanitary shelter, wholesome food and water which are consistent with the normal requirements and breeding habits of the animal's size, species and breed. Kennel means an establishment kept for the purpose of breeding, selling or boarding animals or those engaged in training animals. Owner, caretaker or possessor means any person having a right of property of an animal, or who keeps or harbors an animal or who has it in his care, or acts as its custodian or who permits an animal to remain on or about his premises. (Ord. of 11-10-2000, § 1) Sec. 6-2. - Livestock on public ways. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and intentionally allow or permit any horses, cattle, sheep, goats or other livestock to run at large on public roads or streets or to be staked so that they can go upon the streets. (Ord. of 11-10-2000, § 2) State Law reference— Livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq. Sec. 6-3. - Cruelty to animals. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner, caretaker or possessor of any animal to fail to provide shelter, food and water at all times to the extent that the animal suffers, dies or is injured as a result of such neglect. (b) When harnessed or restrained, all animals and fowl shall be harnessed or restrained in such a manner that will not cause injury to the animal. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any cruel act on any animal; nor shall any person harm, maim, or kill any animal or attempt to do so, except that a person may: (1) Defend his person or property, or the person or property of another, from injury or damage being caused or threatened by an animal; or (2) Kill any animal causing or threatening injury or damage to any livestock or poultry. (d) The method used for killing the animal shall be designed to be as humane as reasonably possible under the circumstances. A person who humanely kills, or injures in a good faith attempt to humanely kill, an animal under the circumstances of subsection (c) of this section shall incur no liability for such death or injury. Specifically, shooting an animal with a firearm under the circumstances of subsection (c) of this section in a good faith effort to humanely kill shall be considered "humane" regardless of whether said shooting results in death or injury. (Ord. of 11-10-2000, § 3) State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4. Sec. 6-4. - Prohibited conditions. (a) It shall be unlawful for any owner, caretaker, possessor to allow their animal to run at large or to go upon public property or property of another if said animal is not under the control, restraint or supervision of said owner, caretaker or possessor or if the presence is not authorized by the owner of said real property. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to release any animal on any property, public or private, with the intention of abandoning the animal. (Ord. of 11-10-2000, § 4) Sec. 6-5. - Vaccination of animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor any animal which has not been vaccinated against rabies as required by the rules and regulations established in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 31-19-5. (Ord. of 11-10-2000, § 5) Sec. 6-6. - Animals running at large; impoundment. (a) Any member of the public shall be authorized to apprehend any animal found running at-large in the county. Said animal may be delivered to the Washington-Wilkes Animal Shelter. (b) The impounded animal shall be handled in accordance with the polices of the shelter. (c) If any animal found running at large cannot be safely taken and impounded, said animal may be slain by any law enforcement officer or animal control officer. (Ord. of 11-10-2000, § 6) Sec. 6-7. - General enforcement. (a) The magistrate's court of the county shall have jurisdiction over violations of this section and all procedures for enforcement of this section shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. title 15, chapter 10, article 4 (O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq.). Complaints of violations of any provision contained herein shall be brought before the magistrate's court on a citation issued by the code enforcement officer, the animal control officer or by a law enforcement office. Citations shall meet all the official requirements as specified in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63, as amended. (b) Any person who violates the provisions contained herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished according to section 1-9, general penalty. (Ord. of 11-10-2000, § 7)

div.head: Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; fire escapes in buildings, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 8-1—8-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BUILDING PERMITS
Sec. 8-19. - Permit required. A building permit shall be required for any new construction, any addition to, alteration of, repair to, or relocation of old construction, setting up of factory-built housing and industrialized buildings by any individual, partnership, or corporation within the unincorporated area of the county in which such work or value of the structure shall be in excess of $4,500.00. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 200, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 200, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-20. - Owner of property and/or contractor to make application before commencement of construction. The permit application shall be made by the owner of the property and/or contractor performing the work prior to the commencement of any work activity, and no work shall be performed prior to the granting of a permit. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 201, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 201, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-21. - Application made to tax appraiser. Application for a building permit shall be made to the tax appraiser of the county on a form approved by the county and provided for such purpose. Further, a copy of the plat of the property shall be attached to the building permit and a copy of construction plans shall be provided to the tax appraiser when plans are used for the construction project. The plan owner may retrieve said plans within six months after final inspection. If not retrieved within the six-month period, plans will become property of the county and will be subject to disposal. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 202, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 202, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-22. - Minimum lot size. No building intended for use as a residential dwelling unit shall be constructed or moved to any lot with an area of less than 43,560 square feet, except in an approved subdivision. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 203, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 203, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-23. - Governmental or public utility connections. (a) No connection for service of electricity by a public utility shall be made until after the granting of a written permit by the building inspector as provided by this article. (b) The governmental or public utility asked to provide service to a location for any class of work as set forth in section 8-19 shall be provided with and have in its possession a signed copy of the original permit issued by the tax assessor's office. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 300, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 300, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-24. - Issuance of permit. The tax assessor shall have up to seven days after the date the fully completed application and all attachments thereto are received, including a copy of a plat of the property, a copy of construction plans, and a copy of a certificate of approval of septic tank from the county health department to issue a building permit. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 400, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 400, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-25. - Permit display on premises. The permit issued by the tax assessor's office shall be prominently displayed on the premises where the work is being done or the setting up of factory-built housing or an industrialized building, is taking place. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 401, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 401, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-26. - Payment of fees subject to issuance or approved amendment of permit. A permit shall not be issued until the fees prescribed in this article have been paid. Nor shall an amendment to a permit be approved until the additional fee, if any, due to an increase in the estimated cost of the building or structure, shall have been paid. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 500, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 500, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-27. - Accurate records. The county shall keep a permanent and accurate accounting of all permit fees and other monies collected, the name of all persons upon whose account the same was paid, the date and amount thereof. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 501, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 501, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-28. - Schedule of permit fees. On all buildings, structures, or alterations requiring a permit, a fee for each permit shall be paid as required at the time of filing of the application, in accordance with the following schedules. (1) Buildings and improvements. a. Single-family (including factory-built housing and industrialized buildings): The permit fees shall be established by the board, from time to time. Note: Mobile homes and pre-fab buildings that already have built-in plumbing may be excluded from the plumbing fee. This exclusion will also apply to built-in mechanical. b. Non-commercial; outbuildings and swimming pools (e.g., storage buildings, shops, barns, etc.); structures not attached to homes; single-family dwellings, mobile homes, pre-fab homes; buildings with a value of less than $100,000.00: The permit fees shall be established by the board, from time to time. c. Commercial, industrial, multi-family, public, and accessory fee schedule: The permit fees shall be established by the board, from time to time. d. Moving of building or structure. For the moving of a building or other structure, the fee shall be established by the board from time to time. e. Demolition of building or structure. For the demolition of a building or structure, a permit is required. A complimentary permit shall be issued to the building or structure owner, however failure to obtain the permit prior to the demolition of such building or structure shall constitute a violation of this regulation and require payment to be established by the board, from time to time. (2) Electrical. The fees for service size shall be established by the board, from time to time. Each circuit connected in panel shall be in an amount established by the board from time to time, in addition to the charges in this subsection. Double pole circuits shall be considered as one circuit. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 502, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 502, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-29. - Reinspection. If it is necessary to make a reinspection for a required building or electrical inspection because of improper work, the owner or contractor shall pay a reinspection fee to be determined by the board from time to time. (Ord. No. 041389B, § 503, 4-13-1989; Ord. No. 07092015B, § 503, 7-9-2015) Secs. 8-30—8-46. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION CODES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26.
Sec. 8-47. - Standard building codes. (a) Unless otherwise provided for by subsequent ordinance or another provision of this Code, the county hereby adopts and incorporates by reference, as if set out at length herein, the latest editions of the state minimum standard codes enumerated in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20(9)(b), as adopted and amended by the department of community affairs. (1) International Building Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (2) International Residential Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (3) Fire Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 Georgia Amendments. (4) International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (5) International Mechanical Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (6) International Fuel Gas Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (7) National Electrical Code, 2011 Edition. (8) International Energy Conservation Code, 2009 Edition, with 2011 and 2012 Georgia Supplements and Amendments. (b) If any of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section are adopted as a state minimum code pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., then the edition adopted by the state shall control. If any of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section are less stringent than the state minimum codes promulgated pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., then the state minimum code shall control. (c) A copy of each of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section, as adopted by the state, is filed in the clerk's office and available for review by the public. The same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the county. (Ord. No. 07092015B, § 600, 7-9-2015) Sec. 8-48. - Conflicts. (a) If any of the publications listed are adopted as a state minimum code pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., then the edition adopted by the state shall control. If any of the publications listed are less stringent than the state minimum codes promulgated pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., the state minimum code shall control. (b) A copy of each of the publications listed, as adopted by the state, is filed in the city clerk's office and available for review by the public. The same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the county. Sec. 8-49. - Tests. The county building official may require tests or test reports as proof of compliance. Required tests are to be made at the expense of the owner, or his agent, by an approved testing laboratory or other approved agency. Sec. 8-50. - General inspection required prior to temporary or permanent electrical service connection.
