The ordinance control officer shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (4) Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO zones). Areas of special flood hazard may include designated AO shallow flooding areas. These areas have base flood depths of one to three feet aboveground, with no clearly defined channel. The following provisions apply: a. All new construction and substantial improvements of residential and nonresidential structures shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to the flood depth number specified on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM), above the highest adjacent grade. If no flood depth number is specified, the lowest floor, including basement, shall be elevated at least three feet above the highest adjacent grade. Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with standards of elevated buildings. The ordinance control officer shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. b. New construction or the substantial improvement of a nonresidential structure may be floodproofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be water tight to the specified FIRM flood level plus one foot, above highest adjacent grade, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and as required. c. Drainage paths shall be provided to guide floodwater around and away from any proposed structure. (5) Standards for subdivisions. a. All subdivision proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; b. All subdivision proposals shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage; c. All subdivision proposals shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards; and d. Base flood elevation data shall be provided for subdivision proposals and all other proposed development, including manufactured home parks and subdivisions, greater than 50 lots or five acres, whichever is less. (Ord. No. 031704, § VIII, § 8.3, 3-17-2004) Secs. 24-140—24-161. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - SUPPLEMENTARY REGULATIONS
Sec. 24-162. - Personal care homes. In districts where personal care homes are permitted as conditional uses, the following restrictions must be met: (1) Location. No personal care home shall be located in areas where the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the home would be compromised. Examples of such areas would be near industrial sites or other sites where environmental quality would be poor, and also areas where law enforcement records indicate that the incidence of crime is high. (2) Proximity to other personal care homes. No personal care home shall be located less than 1200 feet from an existing or proposed personal care home. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.1, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-163. - Signs/outdoor advertising. Reserved. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.2, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-164. - Off-street parking and loading. (a) General requirements. (1) All off-street automobile storage or parking facilities shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street or lane. Except for single-family dwellings fronting on a minor or local street, no required off-street parking facilities shall be arranged so as to require backing from the space directly onto a public street. (2) Off-street parking plans shall be submitted as part of the proposed site plans. Such plans shall show the proposed layout of all parking areas, the total number of off-street parking spaces to be provided, and the dimensions of the typical individual parking space. Off-street parking plans including driveways and curb cuts shall be reviewed by the planning commission staff. (3) Individual parking spaces shall have the minimum dimensions of ten feet in width and 20 feet in length unless off-street parking is to be provided in common parking bays or lots. (4) Off-street parking spaces and lots shall be graded to provide adequate drainage and shall be paved with an all-weather material or equivalent surface subject to the approval of the county or county engineer. (5) Along those lot lines of an off-street parking area that abuts residential districts, a solid screen of no less than five feet in height shall be erected. The screen shall begin five feet from the right-of-way line of a public street and continue for the entire length of the property lines abutting a residential district. (6) No curb cuts shall be allowed within 25 feet of the intersection of the right-of-way line of two public streets. Except in residential zones, no curb cut shall be allowed within 25 feet of any other curb cut on or off the site, nor shall any curb cut be allowed within 12½ feet of any property line. (7) Any light used to illuminate required parking areas shall be arranged so that the light is reflected away from adjacent properties. (8) No sign (permanent or temporary), light standard, or screening material shall be placed so as to inhibit the orderly use of a parking facility or in a manner which reduces the number of usable parking spaces. No sign, light standard, or screening material shall be placed so that it obstructs visibility for drivers or pedestrians. (9) All off-street parking spaces or lots shall be marked by a durable painted stripe designating no less than the required minimum parking areas. (10) No motor vehicle repair work of any kind shall be permitted in conjunction with off-street parking areas except minor repair on vehicles owned by the occupant or resident of the principal use for which the off-street parking is intended. (11) If the required off-street parking space cannot reasonably be provided on the same lot, tract, or parcel on which the principal use is conducted, the applicant may be permitted to provide such space on other off-street property, provided such space lies within 300 feet of the property line of the principal use. Such space may be parking provided for other uses, provided the utilization of the parking area by the proposed uses do no conflict with the activities associated with the primary use, and that the applicant obtains written authorization for utilization of the parking facility on a continuing basis. (12) The off-street parking requirements contained herein shall not apply to single-family dwellings. (b) Off-street parking requirements for all use zones. Off-street automobile parking or storage facilities shall be provided on every lot, tract, or parcel on which any permitted use or conditional use is established in accordance with this article. Off-street parking or storage space shall be provided with vehicular access to a public street and shall be equal to or greater than the minimum requirements set forth as follows: (1) Uses involving general assembly of the public: One space for every four seats in the main assembly area. (2) Professional uses: At least one space of off-street parking for every 200 square feet of gross floor area. (3) Retail uses: At least one space for every 200 square feet of building area. (4) Drive-in retail uses: At least one space for every 100 square feet of building area. (5) Restaurants: One space for every 200 square feet of building area. (6) Other approved uses: At least one space for every 200 square feet of gross floor area. (7) Multi-family dwellings: At least two spaces for every residential unit in the development. (c) Uses not specified. In the case of a use not specifically mentioned in article III, IV, V or VI of this chapter, the requirements for off-street parking facilities shall be determined by the planning commission. Such determination shall be based upon the requirements set forth for the most comparable use specified in article III, IV, V or VI of this chapter. (d) Reduction in number of required off-street parking spaces. The planning commission may, at its discretion, reduce the minimum number of parking space required for a specific use provided that sufficient evidence is presented justifying the need for such reduction in the requirements and every effort has been made to provide off-street parking in accordance with the stipulations. (e) Parking space design. (1) Each parking space shall be no less than 200 square feet in area. (2) Appropriate directional signage or road paintings shall be applied to each parking lot in order to direct traffic and minimize traffic conflict. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.3, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-165. - Street access controls. In order to promote the safety of the motorist and pedestrians and to minimize traffic congestion and conflict, the following regulations shall apply: (1) Vehicular access from lots to streets shall not exceed 40 feet in width. (2) No more than two points of vehicular ingress/egress from a property to any abutting public street shall be permitted for each 150 feet of lot frontage or fraction thereof; provided, however that lots with less than 100 feet of frontage shall have not more than one point of access to each abutting public street. (3) No access to a state or federal route shall be permitted without the prior approval of the state department of transportation. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.4, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-166. - Nonconforming uses. (a) Repairs and alterations. (1) Repairs and alterations may be made up to 50 percent of the structure valuation as assessed by the county board of tax assessors or its successor, at the time the petition is presented. (2) No structural alterations will be permitted except as provided for in subsection (h) of this section. (3) No enlargements will be permitted except as provided for in subsection (h) of this section. (b) Nonconforming lots. A building or structure nonconforming as to regulations for use or lot area or for dwelling units shall not be added to or enlarged in any manner unless said building or structure including such addition and enlargement is made to conform to the use and area in accordance with regulations of the zone in which it is located except as provided for in subsection (h) of this section. (c) Continuation or change of use. (1) The nonconforming use of a building or structure lawfully existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived may be continued. (2) The nonconforming use of a building or structure may be changed only to a use of the same or a more restricted classification. (d) Expansion. A nonconforming use of a portion of a building or structure designed for and presently in a conforming use shall not be expanded or extended into any other portion of such conforming building or structure nor changed except to a conforming use. (e) Nonconforming land. The nonconforming use of land (where no building is involved) lawfully existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived may be continued provided that no nonconforming use of land shall be expanded or extended either on the same or adjoining property. (f) Nonconforming due to reclassification. The foregoing provisions of this section shall also apply to buildings, structures, land, or uses which hereinafter become nonconforming due to any reclassification of zones under this article or any subsequent change in the regulations of this article. (g) Abandoned nonconforming use. Any nonconforming use which has been abandoned for a period of one year or more shall not be used for any purpose other than that permitted in the zone in which such use is situated. (h) Structural alterations and enlargement. An existing nonconforming use may be permitted to expand in the district in which it is located upon approval by the planning commission, provided that: (1) A site plan showing the existing nonconforming land and buildings and the proposed expansion has been submitted for approval; (2) The existing nonconforming use is a type permitted under the C-1 (commercial district) zone and article V of this chapter; (3) The enlargement does not exceed 20 percent of the square footage contained within the existing nonconforming structure, the amount of expansion permitted to be calculated using the square footage on record with the county board of tax assessors; (4) The expansion shall not extend beyond the property lines of the existing nonconforming use except where additional land is acquired to meet the off-street parking requirements of section 24-139; (5) The expansion is in compliance with all setback and yard requirements of the zone in which the nonconforming use is located; (6) Off-street parking and loading are provided in accordance with section 24-164; (7) The expansion does not involve the construction of any separate structures; and (8) No previous expansion has occurred under the provisions of this section. (i) Exceptions. Any new use permitted as a conditional use or granted a variance under the terms of this article shall not be deemed a nonconforming use, but shall without further action be considered a conforming use. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.5, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-167. - Manufactured homes. (a) Permits. Any dwelling which is classified as a manufactured home by the definition stated herein shall be subject to the following provisions of this article: A building permit shall be required to be filed in the tax assessors' office for each manufactured home which is henceforth located in the county. (1) Each year every owner of a manufactured home subject to taxation under this article shall obtain on or before May 1 from the tax collector, or tax commissioner of the county of taxation of the manufactured home, a manufactured home location permit. The issuance of the permit by the tax collector or tax commissioner shall be evidenced by the issuance of a decal, the color of which shall be prescribed for each year by the commissioner. Each decal shall reflect the county of issuance and the calendar year for which the permit is issued. The decal shall be prominently attached and displayed on the manufactured home by the owner. (2) Each year every owner of a manufactured home situated in this state on January 1 which is not subject to taxation under this article shall obtain on or before May 1 from the tax commissioner of the county where the manufactured home is situated a manufactured home location permit. The issuance of the permit shall be evidenced by the issuance of a decal which shall reflect the county of issuance and the calendar year for which the permit is issued. The decal shall be prominently attached and displayed on the manufactured home by the owner. (3) It shall be unlawful to fail to attach and display on a manufactured home the decal as required by subsection (a)(1) of this section. (4) Any person who violates subsection (a)(1) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $200.00, except that upon receipt of proof of purchase of a decal prior to the date of the issuance of a summons, the fine shall be $25.00. (5) It shall be unlawful for any person to move or transport any manufactured home which is required to and which does not have attached and displayed thereon the decal provided for in subsection (a)(1) of this section. a. Any person who violates this subsection (a)(5) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 12 months, or both. b. Violation of subsection (a)(1) of this section or this subsection (a)(5) may be prosecuted in the magistrate court of the county where the manufactured home location permit is to be issued in the manner prescribed for the enforcement of county ordinances. (6) The chief tax appraiser, the members of the board of tax assessors and the personal property appraiser together with the building inspector or other duly authorized code enforcement personnel shall have the authority to issue citations for violations of this section. (7) Violations of this article shall be brought by citation issued by an authorized representative of the board of commissioners before the magistrate's court of the county. Said citation shall be issued and the matter shall be heard in accordance with the procedures adopted by said magistrates court and the provisions of general law regarding magistrate's courts. (b) Lot area. The lot area shall be one acre (43,560 square feet) or greater; and dimensions must meet the requirements of the county health department in regard to water and sewer systems; provided further, said lot shall be delineated by plat and said plat shall be recordable. One manufactured home as a second and temporary accessory dwelling may be allowed only in the case of hardship as herein defined. (1) The manufactured home is an accessory use on a lot that meets all of the requirements of this article, further provided that the occupant of the manufactured home and the occupant of the principal dwelling are closely related, as, for example, father, mother, son, or daughter. (2) The manufactured home is not located within any required front or side yard. (3) Once a hardship or other conditions described in subsection (b)(1) of this section have terminated, the second and temporary accessory manufactured home shall be removed. (c) On lots exceeding five acres in size additional manufactured homes shall be allowed for tenant dwellings and other uses, provided that said uses shall not be inconsistent with the manufactured home park regulations contained herein and provided further that the number of said additional manufactured homes in such areas shall not exceed the ratio of one such unit per five acres of land. (d) No manufactured home older than ten years from the date of manufacture shall be brought into the county for the purpose of establishing a residence, business, or for any other purpose. No manufactured home older than 15 years from the date of manufacture shall be moved from one location to another within the county, except that the owner may relocate the manufactured home from one place to another when the manufactured home does not leave the owners property. (e) In no case shall the unit be located within 200 feet of any permanent type of building owned by another party; provided the owner of said building may waive in writing this requirement, but provided further that said distance shall be at least 50 feet. (f) The manufactured home unit must have a border or supporting foundation which surrounds all of the exterior walls completely enclosing the under carriage or underside area of the manufactured home. The border or foundation material shall consist of concrete block, brick, wood, composition board or metal skirting or some similar type material. The manufactured home must be connected to water and sewerage as provided in subsection (j) of this section. (g) All manufactured homes used as residences shall meet the adopted building, gas, plumbing, electric, and other codes, if any, of the governmental area. (h) Temporary usage. A single manufactured unit may be used as an office in a subdivision by the developer, temporary residence during construction of permanent residence, or for other special purposes, for a period not to exceed six months upon written approval from the tax assessor. Extensions may be granted. (i) Nonconformance. After date of approval of the ordinance from which this article is derived, any manufactured home located in the unincorporated areas of the county which does not meet the requirements in the above subsections shall be removed after receipt of notice of its nonconformance from the tax assessor or health officials. (j) All manufactured homes in the county must be served by a water and sewer system approved by the county health department. (k) Manufactured home tiedowns. Any manufactured home which is not anchored may blow over or off its blocks when the wind velocity reaches approximately 70 miles per hour. Therefore, this selection of this article is intended to make certain that all manufactured homes hereafter placed in the area are equipped with tiedowns and anchored. (1) All manufactured homes placed in the unincorporated areas of the county after the adoption of this article shall have tiedowns with provisions for distributing the load of these tiedowns and provisions for distributing the load of these tiedowns and provisions for the attachment to ground anchors so as to resist wind overturning and sliding. (2) Each tiedown shall be designed to resist an allowable working load equal to or exceeding 3,150 pounds and shall be capable of withstanding a 50 percent overload without failure. (l) Ground anchors. Ground anchors shall be installed at each manufactured home stand when a manufactured home is located thereon to permit tiedowns of manufactured homes to comply with this section. (1) Each ground anchor shall be capable of resisting an allowable working load equal to or exceeding 3,150 pounds applied in the direction of the tiedown. In addition, each ground anchor shall be capable of withstanding a 50 percent overload without failure. (2) Ground anchors shall be resistant to weathering deterioration at least equivalent to that provided by a coating of zinc on steel strapping of not less than 0.30 ounces per square foot of surface coated. (m) Manufactured home parks. Manufactured home parks as so defined in these regulations must adhere to the following conditions: (1) The minimum area per park shall be five designated and described acres; the minimum width for portion used for entrance and exit shall be 50 feet; and minimum width for portion containing manufactured home spaces, or stands, shall be 50 feet. (2) The minimum number of spaces or stands that shall be ready for occupancy before the first occupancy is permitted shall be 15 spaces, and the minimum area for each manufactured home space or stand shall be 6,000 square feet. (3) No manufactured home space or stand shall be rented for residential use of a manufactured home in any such park except for periods of 30 days or more, and no manufactured home shall be admitted to any park unless it can be demonstrated that it meets the requirements of any additional laws and regulation of the governing authority. (4) In addition to meeting the above requirements, the manufactured home park site plan shall be accompanied by a certificate of approval from the area health department. (5) No manufactured home shall be located within: a. Ten feet of its individual lot line; b. 25 feet from any exterior boundary of the manufactured home park. (6) A buffer strip at least 25 feet wide shall be located adjacent to each exterior property line of the manufactured home park and not be included within any individual trailer lot. In every manufactured home park the following street improvements and utilities shall be planned for and provided by the developer, by installation and/or payment prior to the approval of the manufactured home park. a. General. All streets shall be named and marked with signs in accordance with county approved names and shall include street grading and street paving. 1. Sanitary sewer lines, septic tanks, or other sewerage disposal system shall be in conformity with requirements of the county health department. 2. All utilities, except power lines and telephone lines, shall be installed underground in the shoulders of the road. b. Base and paving shall meet the requirements of the department of transportation for rural roads. c. Manufactured home park street improvement width shall meet the minimum requirements as defined by the department of transportation for rural roads. d. Linear street grades. Maximum and minimum linear street grades shall be as follows: 1. Collector streets: not more than 12 percent. 2. Sub collectors, lanes, and parking spaces: not more than 15 percent. 3. No linear street grade shall be less than one-half of one percent. e. Storm drainage facilities. 1. A registered engineer must certify that the proposed storm drainage improvements indicated on the manufactured home park plan are adequate. 2. If a storm drainage sewer system exists in the county area, then the proposed manufactured home park must contain an underground storm drainage system which will be connected to the existing area system. Such system shall be indicated on the plat. 3. If a storm drainage sewer system does not exist in the county, the adequate surface drainage facilities as certified by an engineer shall be included in the manufactured home park and so indicated on the plan. 4. Where a proposed manufactured home park is traversed by a watercourse, drainage way, channel, or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way along each side of the channel or course for the purpose of widening, deepening, relocating, improving, or protecting such drainage easement. f. All manufactured home subdivisions shall be required to meet all the standards and provisions of the subdivision regulations of the county. g. All manufactured home places erected or located in the county shall be required to meet the adopted building, heating, plumbing, electrical, fire, gas, mechanical, air conditioning, and all other codes, if any, adopted by the county. h. Penalties to single-family manufactured home owners. Failure by the owner of a manufactured home to obtain and utilize tiedowns and anchors for his manufactured home placed in the county after the effective date of these regulations shall constitute a misdemeanor. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.6, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-168. - Home occupations. In districts where home occupations are permitted as a conditional use, the following restrictions must be met: (1) Application for home occupation must be made to the county planning commission. (2) Such office is situated in the same dwelling unit as the home of the occupant, except in the A district where the office may be housed in an accessory building. (3) The residential character of such dwelling is not changed. (4) For home occupations established after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, there shall be no assistants employed. Home occupations established prior to the effective date may have two assistants. (5) The necessary functions of the home occupation shall not occupy over 25 percent of the floor area of the dwelling unit. (6) Where special equipment is used, the building code of the county, shall govern the size of electrical wiring, plumbing, etc., which must be installed before such home occupation shall begin. (7) One name plaque or sign for each dwelling unit, excluding flashing or animated types and not exceeding 1½ square feet in area, including the name of the occupant and/or any permitted occupation shall be permitted. (8) The county planning commission may deny a home occupation permit if, in its judgment, such occupation will be hazardous or injurious to the welfare of the community or if compliance with the requirements of this section has not been met. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.7, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-169. - Accessory uses. In districts where accessory structures are permitted, the following restrictions must be met: (1) All accessory buildings shall have a setback of not less than ten feet from any property line, including eaves and other overhanging portions of the structure. (2) No accessory building shall be closer than 20 feet from any other structure on the same lot or parcel of land. (3) Where the rear yard abuts upon a street, no accessory building shall be closer to the rear lot line than the required setback for the zone. Manufactured homes shall not be permitted as accessory buildings. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.8, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-170. - Corner lots. Where lots abut a public street on two sides, the front yard setback limits shall apply to each side of the lot abutting a public street. No structure, shrub, or outdoor use shall be placed on a corner lot so as to permanently or temporarily obstruct vision on the street right-of-way intersection. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.9, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-171. - Liquor stores/adult entertainment uses. No liquor store or other use or structures containing adult uses shall be located closer than 1,000 feet to the property line of any existing liquor store or adult entertainment use or the property line of any existing or proposed school, park, library, church, or other public use or structure. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.10, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-172. - Telecommunications facilities. This section will protect the health, safety, and welfare of residential neighborhoods and foster a competitive environment for telecommunications carriers that does not unreasonably discriminate among providers of functionally equivalent personal wireless services and shall not prohibit or have the effect of prohibiting the provision of personal wireless services, and so as to promote the county as a proactive county in the availability of personal wireless telecommunications service. (1) Building codes. To ensure the structural integrity of telecommunications facilities, the owner of a telecommunications facility shall ensure that it is maintained in compliance with standards contained in applicable local building codes and constructed to the EIA/TIA 222-E standards, as published by the Electric Industries Association, which may be amended from time to time. Owners of telecommunications facilities shall conduct periodic inspections of such facilities at least once every five years to ensure structural integrity. Inspections shall be conducted by a qualified independent engineer licensed to practice in the state. The results of such inspection shall be provided to the county commission. (2) Regulatory compliance. All telecommunications facilities must meet or exceed current standards and regulations of the FAA, the FCC, and any other agency of the state or federal government with the authority to regulate telecommunications facilities. (3) Landscaping. Landscaping shall be used to effectively screen the view of the telecommunication facility from adjacent public roads, public property, and residential property. Native vegetation on the site shall be preserved to the greatest practical extent. The applicant shall provide a site plan showing existing significant vegetation to be removed, and vegetation to be replanted to replace the lost. (4) Setbacks. Telecommunications towers shall be set back a distance equal to the height of the tower from any existing residential use. The setback shall be a distance equal to half the height of the tower from any other use. Minimum setbacks for the land use district shall apply. Setback shall be measured from the base of the tower. (5) Co-location. Telecommunications providers shall be required to locate their transmitting facilities on existing towers unless the provider is able to prove that a new tower construction is vitally necessary and unavoidable. (Ord. No. 031704, § IX, § 9.11, 3-17-2004) Secs. 24-173—24-197. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES
Sec. 24-198. - Enforcement. It shall be the duty of the county commission to enforce the provisions of this chapter within the unincorporated area of the county in the manner and from and with the powers provided in the laws of the state and ordinances of the county. The board of county commissioners shall appoint an appropriate enforcement authority. (Ord. No. 031704, § XI, § 11.1, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-199. - Permit issuance. All commissions, boards, departments, officials, and public employees of the county which are vested with the duty or authority to issue permits or licenses shall conform to the provisions of this chapter and shall issue no permit or license for any use, building, or purpose if the same would be in conflict with the provisions of this chapter. Any permit or license issued in conflict with the provisions of this chapter shall be null and void. (Ord. No. 031704, § XI, § 11.2, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-200. - Violations. The erection, construction, alteration, addition, conversion, moving, or maintenance of any building or structure and the use of any land or building which is continued, operated, or maintained, contrary to any provisions of this chapter is hereby declared to be a violation of this chapter and unlawful. The county attorney shall immediately, upon any such violation having been called to his attention, institute injunction, abatement, or any other appropriate action to prevent, enjoin, abate, or remove violation. Such action may also be instituted by any property owner who may be damaged by any violation of this chapter. The remedy provided for herein shall be cumulative and not exclusive, and shall be in addition to any other remedies provided by law. The building inspector shall identify actions not in conformance with this chapter; the county clerk or other county designee shall notify the property owner of the violation via certified mail. If the violation is not corrected within 30 days from the notification, a penalty shall be assessed. (Ord. No. 031704, § XI, § 11.3, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-201. - Penalties. Any person or corporation whether as principal, agent, employee, or otherwise who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and may, upon conviction, be punished by a fine in an amount not to exceed $500.00 and/or imprisonment for a period not to exceed 60 days. (Ord. No. 031704, § XI, § 11.4, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-202. - Interpretation. The county board of commissioners shall provide final interpretation for all provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 031704, § XI, § 11.5, 3-17-2004) Secs. 24-203—24-227. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - APPEALS AND VARIANCES
Sec. 24-228. - Additional duties of the planning commission. In addition to the duties otherwise set forth in this chapter, the planning commission shall: (1) Hear and decide appeals where it is alleged by the appellant that there is error in any order, requirement, permit, decision, determination or refusal made by the county clerk or other administrative official in the carrying out or enforcement of any provision of this article. (2) Hear requests for interpretation of the land use map, and for a decision on any special questions upon which the county clerk or other administrative official is authorized to pass. (3) Hear and make recommendations to the board of commissioners for approval or disapproval of all variances within the terms of this article. (Ord. No. 031704, § XII, § 12.1, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-229. - Appeals to planning commission. An appeal to the planning commission may be made by any person aggrieved, or by any governmental officer, department, board or bureau affected by any decision of the clerk or designee thereof, based in whole or in part upon the provisions of this article. Such appeal shall be taken within 15 days of the action of decision appealed from by filing with the clerk, or designee thereof, a notice of appeal specifying the grounds for such appeal. The clerk, or designee thereof, shall transmit to the planning commission all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken, and shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal or other matters referred to the planning commission. The clerk, or designee thereof, shall cause to be erected, in a conspicuous place on the property in question, a sign giving public notice of the appeal at least 15 days prior to the scheduled hearing. Any party or person may appear at the hearing in person, by agent or by attorney. (Ord. No. 031704, § XII, § 12.2, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-230. - Variances. A property owner or his designated representative, designated in writing and signed by the owner, may make application for a variance, using forms provided by the clerk, or designee thereof. Upon receipt of an application for a variance, the clerk, or designee thereof, shall schedule a public hearing before the planning commission. The clerk, or designee thereof, shall advertise such hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, and shall cause to be erected, in a conspicuous place on the property in question, a sign giving public notice of the appeal at least 15, but no more than 45, days prior to the scheduled hearing. When a producer is requesting to do anything involving poultry houses that requires a variance, any adjacent landowner shall be notified 14 days prior to any hearing with the planning and zoning board. The planning commission shall consider and decide whether to recommend approval or disapproval of all applications for variances within 30 days after such public hearing, and in accordance with the standards set forth in this subsection. Variances from the terms of this article may be recommended by the planning commission in such individual hardship cases of practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship upon a finding by the planning commission based on the following: (1) There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape, or topography; (2) The application of this chapter to this particular piece of property would create an unnecessary hardship; (3) Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved; and (4) Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purpose and intent of this chapter; provided, however, that no variance may be granted for a use of land or building or structure which is prohibited by this chapter. (Ord. No. 031704, § XII, § 12.3, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-231. - Limitations on variances. A variance shall not be considered or granted from the conditions of approval imposed on a property through a land use change granted by the board of commissioners; nor may a minimum lot size required in the applicable land use district be reduced; nor may any use of land or structures be granted that is not permitted by the land use district that is applicable to the property. Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. (Ord. No. 031704, § XII, § 12.4, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-232. - Special use permits. The special use permit procedure is designed to provide the board of commissioners with an opportunity for discretionary review of requests to establish or construct uses or structures which have the potential for a deleterious impact upon the health, safety, and welfare of the public; and, in the event such uses or structures are approved, the authority to impose conditions that are designed to avoid, minimize or mitigate potentially adverse effects upon the community or other properties in the vicinity of the proposed use or structure. (1) Authorized uses. Only those special use permits that are expressly authorized as such in a particular land use district, or elsewhere in this article may be approved. (2) Review of application. The board of commissioners may permit a special use permit as part of a land use map amendment, or by special use permit procedures at any time after a land use map amendment. (3) Application. An application for a special use permit shall be filed, contain such material and be processed in the same general fashion as detailed for land use amendments. (4) Planning commission hearing. Prior to a decision by the board of commissioners, each application for a special use permit shall be the subject of a public hearing and a recommendation made by the planning commission. (5) Board hearing. A duly noticed public hearing on an application for a special use permit shall be held by the board of commissioners and a decision made by it within 90 calendar days of the date on which the application was accepted for processing unless the applicant agrees to a longer time period. (6) Issues for consideration. In considering a special use permit application, the following factors shall be given reasonable consideration. The applicant shall address all the following in its statement of justification or special use permit plat unless not applicable, in addition to any other standards imposed by this article: a. Whether the proposed special use permit is consistent with the comprehensive plan. b. Whether the proposed special use permit will adequately provide for safety from fire hazards and have effective measures of fire control. c. The level and impact of any noise emanating from the site, including that generated by the proposed use, in relation to the uses in the immediate area. d. The glare or light that may be generated by the proposed use in relation to uses in the immediate area. e. The proposed location, lighting and type of signs in relation to the proposed use, uses in the area, and the sign requirements of this article. f. The compatibility of the proposed use with other existing or proposed uses in the neighborhood, and adjacent parcels. g. The location and area footprint with dimensions (all drawn to scale), nature and height of existing or proposed buildings, structures, walls, and fences on the site and in the neighborhood. h. The nature and extent of existing or proposed landscaping, screening and buffering on the site and in the neighborhood. i. The timing and phasing of the proposed development and the duration of the proposed use. j. Whether the proposed special use permit will result in the preservation or destruction, loss or damage of any topographic or physical, natural, scenic, archaeological or historic feature of significant importance. k. Whether the proposed special use permit at the specified location will contribute to or promote the welfare or convenience of the public. l. The traffic expected to be generated by the proposed use, the adequacy of access roads and the vehicular and pedestrian circulation elements (on- and off-site) of the proposed use, all in relation to the public's interest in pedestrian and vehicular safety and efficient traffic movement. m. Whether, in the case of existing structures proposed to be converted to uses requiring a special use permit, the structures meet all code requirements of the county. n. Whether the proposed special use permit will be served adequately by essential public facilities and services. o. The effect of the proposed special use permit on groundwater supply. p. The effect of the proposed special use permit on the structural capacity of the soils. q. Whether the proposed use will facilitate orderly and safe road development and transportation. r. The effect of the proposed special use permit on environmentally sensitive land or natural features, wildlife habitat and vegetation, water quality and air quality. s. Whether the proposed special use permit use will provide desirable employment and enlarge the tax base by encouraging economic development activities consistent with the comprehensive plan. t. Whether the proposed special use permit considers the needs of agriculture, industry, and businesses in future growth. u. The effect of the proposed special use permit use in enhancing affordable shelter opportunities for residents of the county. v. The location, character, and size of any outdoor storage. w. The proposed use of open space. x. The location of any major floodplain and steep slopes. y. The location and use of any existing nonconforming uses and structures. z. The location and type of any fuel and fuel storage. aa. The location and use of any anticipated accessory uses and structures. bb. The area of each use, if appropriate. cc. The proposed days/hours of operation. dd. The location and screening of parking and loading spaces and/or areas. ee. The location and nature of any proposed security features and provisions. ff. The number of employees. gg. The location of any existing and/or proposed adequate on- and off-site infrastructure. hh. Any anticipated odors which may be generated by the uses on-site. ii. Whether the proposed special use permit uses sufficient measure to mitigate the impact of construction traffic on existing neighborhoods and school areas. (7) Conditions and restrictions. In approving a special use permit, the board of commissioners may impose such conditions, safeguards and restrictions upon the premises benefited by the special use permit as may be necessary to avoid, minimize or mitigate any potentially adverse or injurious effect of such special use permits upon other property in the neighborhood, and to carry out the general purpose and intent of this article. Conditions and restrictions may include, but are not limited to, those related to fencing, planting or other landscaping, additional setbacks from property lines, location and arrangement of lighting, setting of reasonable time limitations and other reasonable requirements deemed necessary to safeguard the interest of the general public. The board may require a guarantee or bond to ensure that conditions imposed will be complied with. All required conditions shall be set out in the documentation approving the special use permit. (8) Effect of issuance of a permit for a special use permit. The issuance of a permit for a special use permit shall not authorize the establishment or extension of any use nor the development, construction, reconstruction, alteration or moving of any building or structure, but shall merely authorize the preparation, filing and processing of applications for any permits or approvals which may be required by the codes and ordinances of the county, including, but not limited to, a building permit, a certificate of occupancy, site plan and subdivision approval and a land use permit. (9) Period of validity. a. Authorization of a special use permit shall be void after two years or such lesser time as the authorization may specify unless substantial construction has taken place. However, the board of commissioners may extend authorization for an additional period not to exceed one year, upon request by the applicant. b. If any special use authorized by this article is discontinued for a period exceeding two years, it shall be deemed abandoned, and the special use permit shall be void. (Ord. No. 031704, § XII, § 12.5, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-233. - Appeal against the board of commissioners. Any person aggrieved because of the alleged error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the planning commission, board of commissioners, or any other party in the enforcement of this article, any time, may take an appeal to the superior court of the county. Said appeal to the superior court shall be the same as an appeal to the superior court as specified in title 5, chapter 3 (O.C.G.A. § 5-3-1 et seq.) of the Code of Georgia, except, however, that said appeal may be filed within 30 days from the date of the decision of the planning commission, the board of commissioners or of any official charged with the enforcement of any order, requirement or decision in connection therewith; and upon failure to file said appeal within 30 days, the said decision of the board of commissioners or planning commission shall be final. (Ord. No. 031704, § XII, § 12.6, 3-17-2004) Secs. 24-234—24-259. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - LOCATION AND MAINTENANCE OF MAPS
Sec. 24-260. - Land use map. The official land use map of the county shall be located in the office of the county planning commission. It shall be the responsibility of the board of commissioners to keep current and maintain the official land use map. (Ord. No. 031704, § XIII, 3-17-2004) Secs. 24-261—24-283. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIII. - LAND USE ORDINANCE AMENDMENTS
Sec. 24-284. - Review of proposed amendments. This article, including the map, may be amended from time to time, but no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by, or first submitted to, the planning commission for review and recommendation. (1) The planning commission shall conduct, on behalf of the county commission, all public hearings on proposed amendments to this article and maps. (2) At least 15 but not more than 45 days prior to the date of the hearing, the planning commission shall cause to be published within a newspaper of general circulation within the territorial boundaries of the local government a notice of the hearing. The notice shall state time, place, and purpose of the hearing. If a land use decision of a local government is for the redistricting of property and the redistricting is initiated by a party other than local government, then: a. The notice shall include the location of the property, the present land use classification of the property, and the proposed land use classification of the property; and b. A sign indicating the present land use classification shall be placed in a conspicuous location on the property not less than 15 days prior to the date of the hearing. (3) The recommendations of the planning commission shall be submitted to the county commission within 30 days. If the planning commission fails to submit a report within the 30-day period, it shall have deemed to approve the proposed amendment. (Ord. No. 031704, § XIV, § 14.1, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-285. - Application for amendment. Each application to amend this article, including the map, shall be filed with the planning commission and shall be in compliance with the following: (1) A conference with the planning commission and county commission shall be held prior to submission of the application. (2) A statement from the owner of the property submitting the petition, or a statement from the owner of the property designating his representative in the petition, shall be furnished with the petition on a form supplied by the planning commission. (3) A properly prepared plat of the property showing distances and bearings of the boundaries and a tie to a known point shall be included with the petition. (4) A letter from the owner or his authorized representative requesting the amendment, including a statement regarding the proposed use, address, and telephone number for correspondence, and any other information required elsewhere in this article, shall be included with the petition. (5) A fee that has been calculated by the planning commission as representative of the cost of processing and advertisement of the proposed amendment shall be listed on the county current fee schedule and shall be paid at the time of application. (Ord. No. 031704, § XIV, § 14.2, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-286. - Planning commission action. The planning commission shall review and make a recommendation of approval, denial, deferral, withdrawal without prejudice, or no recommendation, on each application at a public hearing held in accordance with this article of the commission of the county. Staff recommendations on application shall be submitted to the planning commission prior to the public hearing. A report of the planning commission's decision shall be submitted to the governing body. The action of the planning commission may recommend a reduction of the land area for which the request is made and/or recommend conditions of redistricting which may be deemed advisable so that the purpose of this article will be served. (Ord. No. 031704, § XIV, § 14.3, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-287. - Governing body action. The governing body having jurisdiction of the property under consideration shall, at a regular meeting, approve, deny, or defer action on such application. The action of the governing body may recommend a reduction of the land area for which the application is made and/or recommend conditions of districting which may be deemed advisable so that the purpose of this article will be served. When such conditions are added to approval of an application, the governing body may require that a land use restriction agreement be recorded with the clerk of the superior court of the county. The cost of recording such agreement shall be borne by the applicant. (Ord. No. 031704, § XIV, § 14.4, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-288. - Reversionary clause. The planning commission may submit information to the governing body having jurisdiction relative to property which has been rezoned for a period of 18 months from the date of approval, and for which no site plan or subdivision development plan approval has been obtained. The governing body may then review such information and, if considered appropriate, initiate reversionary land use procedures. Such reversionary actions shall proceed in accordance with the amendment provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 031704, § XIV, § 14.5, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-289. - Repeat redistricting attempts. When an application for redistricting is defeated, either by the county commission or ultimately on appeal, the same property may not again be considered for redistricting until the expiration of at least six months immediately following the defeat of the redistricting. (Ord. No. 031704, § XIV, § 14.6, 3-17-2004) Secs. 24-290—24-311. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIV. - SEPARABILITY AND ABROGATION
Sec. 24-312. - Separability. If any section, clause, provision, or portion of this chapter shall be ruled invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect any other section, clause, provision, or portion of this chapter. (Ord. No. 031704, § XV, § 15.1, 3-17-2004) Sec. 24-313. - Abrogation. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are repealed. (Ord. No. 031704, § XV, § 15.2, 3-17-2004) Secs. 24-314—24-344. - Reserved. ARTICLE XV. - TABLE OF PERMITTED/PROHIBITED USES
Sec. 24-345. - Purpose. The following table should be used as reference only. Some uses or land use districts may have additional restrictions. Articles II, III, IV, V and VI of this chapter should be consulted for additional restrictions or requirements. P = Permitted use A = If applicable
(Ord. No. 031704, § XVI, 3-17-2004)

div.head: Chapter 26 - ROADS AND BRIDGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, streetlights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); damaging public property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; Georgia Code of Public Transportation, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-1 et seq.; governmental authorization for construction or maintenance of any private road unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-8; state, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; county road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-40 et seq.; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; inspection of and reports on roads and bridges by county police, O.C.G.A. § 36-8-6; grants for construction and maintenance of county roads, O.C.G.A. § 36-17-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 26-1. - Base map; official system of street and road names established. There is established an official system of street and road names as shown on the base map entitled Base Map—Wilkes County, Georgia, Dated July 12, 1990, as produced by the Central Savannah River Area Regional Development Center, a copy of which is made a part of this chapter. (Ord. No. 071290-A, § 1, 7-12-1990) Sec. 26-2. - Street names in the unincorporated areas of the county. The names of streets and roads of the unincorporated areas of the county shall remain as shown on said map, unless officially changed by ordinance. (Ord. No. 071290-A, § 2, 7-12-1990) Sec. 26-3. - Acceptance of new streets and municipal improvements of the county. No new streets or roads shall be accepted by the county and no municipal improvements shall be made therein until such street or road has been properly named. If said street or road is an extension of an existing street or road, the existing name shall be continued. If not an extension of an existing street or road, names recorded shall not duplicate or closely approximate street or road names that have already been assigned. (Ord. No. 071290-A, § 3, 7-12-1990) Sec. 26-4. - Maintenance of streets. The county planning commission shall be responsible for maintenance of the system of street and road names. The planning commission shall maintain a copy of the map adopted by this chapter and shall record thereon all changes made by ordinance or new assignments accepted by subdivision platting or other legal means. The planning commission shall cause to be made revisions to the official map to include all official changes made up to date of revision, which is also to be clearly recorded thereon. (Ord. No. 071290-A, § 4, 7-12-1990) Secs. 26-5—26-26. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ROADS AND RIGHT-OF-WAY USE
Sec. 26-27. - Permit required. No person shall begin to construct, re-construct, repair, alter or grade any right-of-way at any private entrance, exit, ramp, bridge, side road or other vehicular passageway, on the public county roads within the unincorporated areas of the county without first obtaining a permit from the tax assessor's office in the manner specified in this article. No person (contractor or property owner) shall utilize any existing county road right-of-way for ingress or egress to private property within the unincorporated areas of the county for the purpose of doing construction, grading, land improvements, logging, pulpwooding, timber harvesting and other operations without first obtaining a permit from the tax assessor's office in the manner specified in this article. The routine maintenance, grading, graveling of a private road or driveway by the owner or by the contractor for the owner shall not require a permit and shall not be subject to this article. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 1, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-28. - General standards for issuance of special temporary right-of-way entry permit. Said permit shall apply to both new and existing right-of-way entry. The tax assessor's office shall issue a permit hereunder when the applicant agrees to the following: (1) That the work shall be done according to the standard specifications of the county for public work of like character; (2) That the operation will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and pedestrian traffic or the means of ingress to and egress from the affected and adjacent properties; (3) That the health, welfare and safety of the public will not be unreasonably impaired; and (4) That the roadways will not be damaged and proper water drainage will not be adversely affected. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 2, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-29. - Construction and supervision. (a) All work for which a permit is granted hereunder shall be constructed according to the specifications established by the county so that the drainage, access, compaction, materials, dimensions, slope, width and other aspects of its conservation shall not unreasonably interfere with traffic flow and drainage considerations. (b) All construction for which a special temporary right-of-way entry permit is granted hereunder shall be under the direction and supervision of the public works director or his designee who shall have the authority to order the applicant to immediately cease all operations when applicant does not construct and maintain the right-of-way entry according to county standards. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 3, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-30. - Application. (a) Every person required to procure a special temporary right-of-way entry permit under the provisions of this article shall submit a written application for such permit to the tax assessor's office. (b) The written application shall state the following: (1) The name and address and telephone number of the applicant. (2) The name and address and telephone number of the property owner. (3) The location of the right-of-way entry including map and parcel information. (4) The purpose for which the application is submitted. (5) The nature and location of any work proposed to be done and the name of the person or firm who is to do such work, inclusive of their contact inform. (6) The date of commencement and the date of completion of the proposed work and other data or plans as may reasonably be required by the public works director of the county. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 4, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-31. - Plan required. Prior to issuance of any permit, the applicant shall submit a plan of all right-of-way entries to be used for such operations which are adjacent to any public road, to include graveling when required by weather conditions. The public works director shall have the authority to require suitable materials and installation of a pipe under such right-of-way entries. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 5, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-32. - Issuance of permit. The tax assessor's office, after a review of the application, shall issue a permit. The permit shall be valid for the permitted site until released or terminated pursuant to the terms of this article. The public works director shall have the authority to revoke a permit when determined that this policy is or has been violated. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 6, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-33. - Appeal of decision on revocation of permit. (a) An appeal may be taken to the board of commissioners of the county by any applicant affected by the decisions the public works director of the county within 30 days after the date of the decision of the public works director. The decision of the public works director shall be final upon failure of any aggrieved applicant within 30 days allowed to file an appeal to the board of county commissioners. (b) Any applicant aggrieved by the decision of the board of commissioners may take an appeal to the superior court of the county. The appeal shall be filed within 30 days from the date of the decision of the board of county commissioners. The decision of the board of county commissioners shall be final upon failure of any aggrieved applicant to file an appeal within the 30 days allowed to file in the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 7, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-34. - Display of permit. It shall be the duty of any applicant hereunder to display the permit issued to him in a conspicuous place at the site of the right-of-way entry. It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit such permit at or about any location not covered thereby, or to misrepresent the number of the permit or the date of the permit. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 8, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-35. - Limitation on issuance. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no permit shall be issued to any applicant therefor who has failed to satisfy any bonding requirements imposed in section 26-36. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 9, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-36. - Bond. (a) An applicant for a permit hereunder shall file a cash bond or letter of credit from a lending institution in the amount of $1,000.00 with his application and shall agree to indemnify and hold harmless the county board of commissioners and any of their agents from all damages and cost of repairs to any county road, county rights-of-way, ditches and bridges. Any person, corporation, business, partnership or any other entity needing to cross the right-of-way of county roads in the unincorporated area of the county shall obtain a permit from the county prior to the start of any operations and disturbances of any county right-of-way and shall covenant and shall guarantee he will maintain the county roads right-of-way, including, but not limited to, its roads, bridges, ditches, pipes, culverts, drainage ditches in accordance with county standards and shall repair any damages to the county right-of-way (property) within 30 days from written notice from county of any damages or problems. (b) After completion of the project, the applicant shall remove the right-of-way entry and restore the right-of-way to its original condition. The bond may be released provided all corrections, repairs and improvements have been made by the applicant within the time limits stated herein. (c) Failure of the applicant to perform the corrections of any specific problem within 30 days after completion of the project shall result in forfeiture of the bond. (d) In the event the applicant fails to correct any damages within 30 days after completion of the project or within 30 days from written notice from county, whichever first occurs, the county may correct all damages and all costs and charges to the county for the corrective work shall be the responsibility of the applicant. (e) Said applicant shall reimburse the county within 30 days after he is presented with a written bill for corrective work done by the county. The county shall use the bond as an offset to the costs and if the costs of the corrective work exceeds the value of said bond, the applicant shall be responsible for the deficit balance. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 10, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014) Sec. 26-37. - Violation. Any person, corporation, business, partnership or any other entity who performs activity in violation of this article shall be subject to a fine and/or confinement under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20. A violation of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be tried in the county magistrate court and, upon conviction, shall be punished according to section 1-9, general penalty. (Ord. No. 11142013RD, § 11, 11-14-2013; Ord. of 1-9-2014)

div.head: Chapter 28 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 28-1. - Purpose. This chapter is enacted for the purpose of promoting the general health and welfare of the county by providing for the proper, efficient, and sanitary disposal of waste. (Ord. No. 071494A, § 100, 7-14-1994; Ord. of 12-13-2001) Sec. 28-2. - Short title. This chapter shall be known as the "Solid Waste Ordinance." (Ord. No. 071494A, § 200, 7-14-1994; Ord. of 12-13-2001) Sec. 28-3. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this regulation, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Collection area means an area provided or designated by the county to be used for the collection and disposal of garbage and solid waste and/or for the location of collection containers. Collection container means a container provided by the county and placed in the unincorporated area thereof to be used for the collection and disposal of certain waste defined herein. Collection container waste means garbage, rubbish, refuse of any and all types regardless of origin, including household, business and commercial garbage and trash, provided that the same does not exceed four cubic feet in area and does not exceed three feet in length in any dimension. The term "collection container waste" shall also, in all instances, exclude leaves, limbs, bushes, trees, roots, dead animals, appliances, equipment, bed springs, mattresses, furniture, construction wastes including asbestos, bricks, blocks, rocks, lumber, asphalt, cement, concrete, concrete products or waste, roofing, sheetrock, tires, motors, engines, chemical wastes, scrap metal, fence wire, vehicles or parts thereof, as well as refused wastes as defined herein. County shall be deemed to refer to the area of the county outside the corporate limits of the Town of Rayle, Town of Tignall, and City of Washington. Person shall be deemed to mean any entity, person, firm, partnership, corporation or unincorporated association. Refused waste means waste that cannot be lawfully accepted and disposed of by the county transfer station or recycling program given its permit and state and federal regulations at the time. The term "refused waste" includes, but is not limited to, asbestos, tires, chemicals, liquids, oil, fuel, bio-medical waste, lead-acid batteries, regulated wastes and hazardous wastes. Road means and includes any road, street, highway, alley, lane, court, and other thoroughfare, however described or designated. Waste means garbage, rubbish, refuse of any and all types regardless of origin, including household garbage and trash, leaves, limbs, bushes, trees, roots, dead animals, appliances, equipment, bed springs, mattresses, furniture business and including business trash and commercial wastes, construction wastes including asbestos, bricks, blocks, rocks, lumber, asphalt, cement, concrete, concrete products or waste, roofing, sheetrock, motors, engines, chemical wastes, industrial or commercial waste or rubbish, scrap metal, fence wire, vehicles or parts thereof and other like items. The term "waste" shall include the terms "collection container waste" and "refused waste." (Ord. No. 071494A, § 300, 7-14-1994; Ord. of 12-13-2001) Sec. 28-4. - Administration and enforcement. (a) The sheriff or deputy or a designated representative of the board of commissioners is hereby granted and shall hereafter have the power and authority to administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection and disposal of garbage and solid waste in the county. (b) Any person violating this article shall be tried before the magistrate court for the county. (c) Upon conviction, a violation of this article may be punished according to section 1-9, general penalty. (Ord. No. 071494A, § 400, 7-14-1994; Ord. of 12-13-2001) Sec. 28-5. - Proper waste disposal required. (a) No person shall dispose of any waste within the bounds of the county except in compliance with this article and/or state law, rules and regulations. (b) Any person desiring to dispose of any waste, excluding refused waste, shall take the same to the county landfill during normal operating hours and dispose of the same as directed by the county employees on duty. In the alternative or in addition thereto, any person desiring to dispose of collection container waste, as defined herein, shall have the option of disposing the same in an approved collection container at a collection site within the county. (Ord. No. 071494A, § 500, 7-14-1994; Ord. of 12-13-2001) Sec. 28-6. - Certain acts prescribed. (a) Any person desiring to transport any waste upon the public roads or thoroughfares in the county, if the same is of a character or substance which is likely to be blown, thrown, slung or deposited from the motor vehicle onto the public rights-of-way, shall secure the waste by containers, tarpaulin, or other device in such fashion as to effectively prevent such deposit on the public rights-of-way. The responsibility to secure the waste shall be applicable alike to the owner of the motor vehicle and the operator thereof. Failure to secure all waste shall be a violation of this article. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of waste generated or originated beyond the boundaries of the county in any collection container in the county, or at the county transfer station (except when authorized by a signed contract with the county) or elsewhere within the boundaries of the county. (1) This shall not limit the power of the board of county commissioners to contract with other governmental entities or other persons for waste disposal in the county. (2) This shall not limit the ability of a property owner to dispose of his waste on his private property or in any duly permitted private landfill or solid waste facility. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any waste at any collection area by placing the same about or around the collection container. All collection container waste must be placed within the container. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any waste by dumping, depositing or disposing of the same by placement upon any road or upon private property not belonging to the party disposing of the same. (e) It shall be unlawful for any person to scavenge in or about any collection container. This shall include climbing in any collection container, removing, examining, or sifting through any of the contents thereof. (f) It shall be unlawful for any person to place or dispose in any county collection container any type of waste defined in section 28-3 under collection container waste as excluded. Specifically excluded items are leaves, limbs, bushes, trees, roots, dead animals, appliances, equipment, bed springs, mattresses, furniture, construction wastes including asbestos, bricks, blocks, rocks, lumber, asphalt, cement, concrete, concrete products or waste, roofing, sheetrock, tires, motors, engines, chemical wastes, scrap metal, fence wire, vehicle or parts thereof as well as refused wastes as defined in section 28-3. Excluded items shall also include any items identified by the state or U.S. Government as items the county is prohibited from handling. (Ord. No. 071494A, § 600, 7-14-1994; Ord. of 12-13-2001) Secs. 28-7—28-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - YARD TRIMMINGS
Sec. 28-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other non-manufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term "municipal solid waste" includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including but not limited to municipal solid waste landfills. Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludge or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing and approved cover thereon. Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Ord. No. 091296A, § 1(1A), 9-12-1996) Sec. 28-32. - Placement and disposal prohibitions. (a) It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with municipal solid waste within the county. (b) Yard trimmings shall not be disposed at any municipal solid waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the county. (c) This article shall be applicable only to the unincorporated area and within any municipality which has not adopted a substantially similar ordinance. (Ord. No. 091296A, § 1(1B), 9-12-1996) Sec. 28-33. - Sorting, storing, composting and collecting procedure. Yard trimmings shall be sorted and stored in the following manner: (1) State law requires local governments to restrict sorting and storing yard trimmings in a manner that facilitates collection, composting or other handling and requires yard trimmings to be beneficially reused or recycled to the maximum extent feasible. (2) The recommended hierarchy for handling yard trimmings in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-21(g) provides for implementing these requirements. (Ord. No. 091296A, § 1(1C), 9-12-1996) Sec. 28-34. - Penalties. (a) Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 per violation or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. (b) Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this article shall be tried before the magistrate court of the county. (Ord. No. 091296A, § 1(1D), 9-12-1996)

div.head: Chapter 30 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Taxation power of county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(a), (b)(2); county taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-220.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 30-1—30-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EXCISE TAX ON CONSUMPTION OF ENERGY[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Excise Tax on Sale or Use of Energy, O.C.G.A. § 43-13-110 et seq.
Sec. 30-19. - Energy excise tax definitions. As used in this article, the terms "dealer," "energy," "local sales and use tax," and "purchaser" shall have the same meanings as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. (Ord. No. 10112012TAX, § 1, 10-11-2012) Sec. 30-20. - Imposition of tax for sales and use. In accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110 et seq., there is imposed within the territorial limits of the special district created pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-111, an excise tax on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy when such sale, use, storage, or consumption would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq., but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (Ord. No. 10112012TAX, § 2, 10-11-2012) Sec. 30-21. - Levy and collection of tax rate; phase-in period. (a) Such excise tax shall be levied and collected by the governing authority of the county pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-112 and 48-13-114 and as provided in this section. (b) Except as otherwise provided in this section, the rate of such excise tax shall be phased in over a four-year period as follows: On or after January 1, 2016, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 100 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (c) In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2(c)(4), if a project of regional significance under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3(92) is started in the special district, it shall not be subject to the phase-in period contained in subsection (b) of this section, and the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy in connection therewith shall be subject to the rate specified in subsection (b) of this section notwithstanding the January 1, 2016, limitation in subsection (b) of this section. (d) Rate. (1) Following such initial imposition during the phase-in time period, on or after January 1, 2016, the rate of the excise tax levied and collected by the governing authority of the county shall be directed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(d).
